 Fundamental Right Law test.
 
 
Since this right is now considered a “fundamental” right the test for challenges to these laws is almost certain to be strict scrutiny. 
 
 The first part of this test is the “compelling” state interest in the regulation. It’s not “we would like this law” or “we prefer this law” or even “we think the law is necessary or advisable.” The state must show that it has a legitimate interest that is so “compelling” it “compels” the passage of the infringing law. Craig, 497 U.S. 836, 852-853 (1990)

Hynes v. Mayor of Oradell, 425 U.S., at 620; First National Bank of Boston v. Bellotti, 435 U.S. 765, 786 (1978).” Schaumburg v. Citizens for a Better Environment, 444 U.S. 620, 637 (1980). It is not enough to show that the Government's ends are compelling; the means must be carefully tailored to achieve those ends. Sable Communications of Cal., Inc. v. FCC, 492 U.S. 115, 126 (1989)
 
 So, the next question is can the Mayor demonstrate that his law is a pin point way to achieve the compelling state interest. 
 
 Finally, the Government must show that the law in question is the “least restrictive means” of addressing the “compelling” interest.
